TeamViewer is just a no-go, especially when working with sensitive information like work related stuff etc.

Currently using its direct IP feature, to connect my work laptop to my desktop computer. Really responsive on LAN, and easy to setup as no relays are needed.

@yarmo Matrix is great and all, but what annoys me the most about community discussions behind "login walls", are they aren't being indexed by search engines... Kind of what I like about GitHub/GitLab/... and mailing lists on the open web.

Another benefit is easy archiving, Internet Archive is great for example!

Like, I wanted a simple stopwatch in the corner on one of my monitors. Kronometer, some Plasma window rules, an application keybinding and I was set.
All FOSS = All LOVE
I love Linux. Litterally endless possibilities! :tux:

@keyoxide @yarmo Just checked all the other stuff being created alongside keyoxide.org, it's basically a whole ecosystem! Very VERY cool!
https://codeberg.org/keyoxide

I feel kind of embarrassed that i didn't even know PGP notations was a thing! 😢
The potential however... :ablobcathyper:

Just randomly stumpled upon @keyoxide by @yarmo. Really cool stuff! 😃 I am definitely going to be adding claim notations to my PGP key when I eventually get some spare time again after exams. :fosstodon:
With that being said, cryptography is pretty neat. Some great minds have contributed really cool stuff to the global collective intelligence throughout the years 🤗
Encryption is hard, great encryption is harder, great encryption AND encryption best practices is the hardest... Nothing is truly stronger than the weakest link.

@hkqd @sotolf @Sire Alacritty is great though! 😁 Recently switched to it from Terminator and am loving the speed! 💨 :rust:
Then to run the command, it is as easy as pressing `home`, `delete` and then `enter`. 😅 Only drawback is not having the bash-completion package helping me out. 😢

Sometimes when running spooky Linux commands, I will prepend a `#` when writing out the command. This will ensure that if accidentally hit enter, the command will just be interpreted as a comment. So something like an `rm -r` or `zfs destory` will not make me cry. 😂

Finally finished my GitHub backup solution. Ended up creating my own hacky tool https://github.com/frederikstroem/github-clone-all which clones all my repos and Gists once every 24 hours to a heavily compressed ZFS dataset on my home server.
@SharksOnCoffee @technomancy As a Dane... I salute the correction 🇩🇰
@wuwei just DuckDuckGo'ed it, looks interesting.
@theDoctor Paper backups definitely also have their charm 😌
Couple that with disc types like the Millennial Disc (M-DISC), and then we're really talking! 🤩

Hard to beat a burnable physical disc for backing up ones most precious data...

I mean, no ransomware gonna be wiping or encrypting my disks! 😤📀💿😤

Even though my TODO lists are just simple Joplin notes that seems to be ever-increasing in size faster than they are shrinked :blobthinkingeyes:

Really highlights the importance of time prioritization... Easier said than done though, feels like a life-long struggle to manage ones time and priorities.
Finishing things on my checklist and then being able to check them off... I can't describe... It just feels so great! ✅ :ablobcatrave:
Currently working on Jekyll, their docs are pretty sweet! 👍

great docs are great

more great docs are greater

making humanity achieve its greatest

Wow, the speed of BLAKE3 is actually kind of insane! Just tried comparing it to SHA512 on my system when hashing a large file. I wonder if there are any apparent drawbacks, 🤔 because otherwise I will probably begin using it as a replacement for SHA512 and SHA256. :rust: :fosstodon:
https://github.com/BLAKE3-team/BLAKE3

more

Currently setting up a Minecraft server for me and my friends, and oh boy do I feel the nostalgia!

But really cool to see the progress that has been made in the modding/plugin community since last time I deployed servers some years ago!

Thinking about choosing 1984 as my next hosting company. Primarily because of their cheap VPS and their promise to use only 100% renewable energy for their servers, (which shouldn't be that hard either in a country like Iceland 😅). 🇮🇸

But I don't know why choosing hosting has to be such a mess, maybe a too saturated market ┐( ∵ )┌ Anyway, any input would be greatly appreciated. This is just what my quick research concluded in terms of cheap, reliable and green hosting... 😊

"Ofelia is a modern and low footprint job scheduler for docker environments, built on Go. Ofelia aims to be a replacement for the old fashioned cron." https://github.com/mcuadros/ofelia

Ofelia seems very promising... 🤔 Much easier than trying to do crazy workarounds like I used too at least 😂 :docker: :github:
I really love to use Keras! It makes working with neural networks sooooo much easier... Such empowering tech, stuff like that is awesome! 😅👌
My LaTeX report is getting totally outta hand, with external library source code listing n' stuff! :ablobcatrave: (Hence the submodules) Haha, learning by doing is amazing 😀
Git submodules are kinda neat tbh :git: https://github.blog/2016-02-01-working-with-submodules/

Kinda weird to share this YouTube link, just confirms Andy Yen's statement, that it's impossible to avoid the big tech companies in today's era... @protonmail :protonmail:
https://youtu.be/LAMl_kpricY

Sad stuff 😢 But important to have the discussion nonetheless. Some real 1984 stuff going on in the world right now!

I'm considering bumping the resources given to my Monero node :monero: It's crazy how many gigs of data flows though that thing! I am kinda wondering what the state of nodes are though, and if the network needs more or not... Like how do I tell?

My assumption are, that most miners with two or more rigs would be running their own full node. But I have nothing to base it on though 😅 Then nodes beyond that would just help stabilize and decentralize the network!?

I made a simple sieve filter for ProtonMail, that automatically discards any emails where the sender is on the spam filter block list. :protonmail:

@hejowhat I'm planning to use https://github.com/josegonzalez/python-github-backup I think, and then make some kind of backup rotation... I recently bought a new 18 TB hard drive, so storage is not too much of an issue :ageblobcat: I considered also making a duplicate to Backblaze B2 as well, but I think that is just a waste 😅
PlatformIO makes microcontroller development soooo much easier! No offense to Arduino's IDE :arduino: but I'm completely unable to use it when coming from VS Code 😅
Listening to podcasts while calmly wiring a breadboard is great! Have done a bit for a university assignment this afternoon, a nice and chill activity for once 😅👌
If Facebook can go down for hours, then why shouldn't GitHub also be able to? 😂

Don't know if I'm becoming too paranoid, but currently I'm dockerizing a complete GitHub backup/dump, to run every 24 hours on my home server 😅
But I mean, better safe than sorry right!? ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

To elaborate on this... I think the transparency benefits citizens, when leaks are disclosed properly by journalist. Another great example is the Snowden leaks, they have personally changed my line of thought drastically!
For lack of better words... Great leaks have always fascinated me. This morning I've been all over the Pandora papers!
One shall not underestimate, the power of a go bag.

I've been using Joplin with Dropbox syncing for a while... Then I found out you can just use Syncthing to sync your Joplin folder, and OMG DO I JUST LOVE IT!

Ended up using git-secret for my server, instead of git-crypt. I think git-secret is more transparent of its operations, and then it also seemed more actively maintained... That being said, is still think there is room for improvements in this space. 🤔 :git:
https://github.com/sobolevn/git-secret
But really cool stuff though!!! Always loving a lil' bit of GPG symmetric-key encryption...

Just toyed around with git-crypt, just a little scary to use in production... Totally gonna mess up tracking a file or something stupid 😅
https://github.com/AGWA/git-crypt

@Tusky I don't have any issues on OnePlus 7 Pro. Really great app, it makes migrating from Twitter much easier. Good thing the apps are well developed, otherwise it would make it impossible for many to easily get up and running on Mastodon. 🙂👍

@mikefordays Oh god yes, same!!! The old VW buses are so fantastic and iconic. Especially the real old ones which normally stinks like **** in the city when they drive by.

Yeah, I mean cars like a Tesla model 3 really gains a ton of range by being crazy aerodynamic. But aerodynamics can for sure now be at a lower priority, because of the amazing technological breakthroughs that has happened over the years. 😊🔋🚀

@utahcon Wow, cool! I feel like I need to go look up some projects on YouTube or something then. 😊 I also think that Tesla initially reconstructed a Mercedes-Benz C-Class for like testing and inspiration or something. Really neat stuff for sure!

@codesections It is of course not just coders who likes Factorio, my mate whom I have the most hours in the game with, is interestingly enough studying to become a smith. I could imagine that it is the engineering smarts, which also really interests him about the game. 😊

It is also most likely the way of thinking which catches engineers (including software engineers) attention I think. Really cool stuff to be honest. 😁 Also the insane stability and optimization of the game really amazes me!

I would love to see it become trendy to reconstruct old combustion cars into electric vehicles… ⚡ Imagine the speed and acceleration!! 🏎

Like a trashed Soviet Lada 4×4 (Lada Niva) or something… Imagine the looks people will give in an intersection, when a Lada just does 0-100 in <3 seconds or something else crazy! 🤣

Also if it is geared for acceleration, at the cost of some top speed maybe. 🤔

What makes Factorio my favorite game, is not so much the game itself, it is however, the amazing developers who share their knowledge and wisdom. 😅 I also quite enjoy the community, which of course also has a ton of coders/developers in it haha. 🤣 🏭 :terminal:

The possibility of moving a lot of heavy industry to space quite fascinates me! Looking at the raw numbers of how much heavy industry pollutes, really indicates the amount of positive impact moving it could have.

The percentage of global emissions heavy industry contributes is about 21 to 22 percent by what I found. A report linked by climate.nasa.gov states 21 percent in 2010. The report: https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/2018/02/ipcc_wg3_ar5_summary-for-policymakers.pdf

@thewk Ubuntu and the Debian system overall really is nice and stable. I also have a ton of scripts that I will now have to rewrite, for instance my apt stuff etc. 😢
I fear switching might end up being quite frustrating, because I have used Ubuntu (+flavors) for all of my :linux: life. But if I know myself right, I got to try Manjaro and see if it is something for me. 😄

@thewk Yeah, I will probably also be waiting a bit for the upgrade myself. But only a singe personal server, with most of my stuff dockerized. So it is not a lot of stuff that can go wrong, and it will be quite easy to restore from backups. 😅

Like curiosity, tinkering, hearing podcasts and reading has been really enjoyable. Same thing for school, but man have there been times I've hated it. Probably more times than I like to admit. 😅

I am totally converted, I will always use Internet Archive links for all future references and links (where it makes sense). I am only increasing information, at the cost of a slight increase in link length.

Okay, so I did not have any luck spoofing a Yahoo e-mail. ProtonMail gave the error: "This email has failed its domain's authentication requirements." and flagged it spam. Might try out a few other big ones later.
@wizzwizz4 Hmm, might test that after I am done being bummed out by this. But thanks for helping out a noob like myself. :)
@wizzwizz4 Yikes, you are right. I tried using my dads e-mail from https://emkei.cz/, it went right through as his. Only the headers that show it was spoofed, and I would never check that manually.
Pro anti-phising tip if you are using ProtonMail (and probably others too): Set up a filter that stars all incoming mails, where the sender is also on your contacts list.

Remember that I will never hesitate to verify my identity using my PGP key!

This is my totally bulletproof plan against identity fraud… /s But in all seriousness, math > random person on the internet. 😅
